channel.title: Money | Mail Online
channel.description: Your complete guide to personal finance and investing with news, predictions, advice, guides and opinion from the financial website of the year.

item.title: HomeServe shares soar after home repair group reveals takeover bids
item.description: Last month, the company acknowledged that it had been the subject of interest from private equity group Brookfield, one of the world's largest alternative investment managers.

item.title: B&M chief executive Simon Arora to retire in 2023
item.description: When the Aroras bought the discount retailer back in December 2004, it was a regional supermarket operator with 21 stores that was struggling to survive.

item.title: BUSINESS LIVE: Retail sales slide as demand weakens; B&M boss to exit
item.description: The FTSE 100 closed down 106.27 points at 7521.68. Among UK companies with reports and updates are B&M and One Me-dia iP Group..

item.title: Will a one-stop multi-asset fund meet your needs in retirement?
item.description: Investing experts frown on only holding one fund given the risk involved, though some will make an exception for a multi-asset fund if it is broad enough.

item.title: Will AJ Bell's new app Dodl with friendly monster take fear out of investing?
item.description: It is aimed at enticing people with five-figure sums tucked away in cash into the stock market for the first time.

item.title: Is it time to close the non-dom taxÂ loophole? Strictly Business debate
item.description: Do potential gains and the large amounts of tax collected from non-doms - on their UK interests - support the case for preserving the current system?

item.title: SMALL CAP MOVERS: One Media iP's golden oldies hit all the right notes
item.description: One Media iP and its catalogue of golden oldies hit all the right notes this week, with its shares climbing 13 per cent to 6.9p.

item.title: Most drivers lose their rag after 3 secs if others don't move off when lights go green
item.description: A new study has examined how quickly Britons are likely to lose their rag when 'slow coaches' don't move off when traffic lights go from red to green.

item.title: BMW's new 7 Series limo debuts bold new looks and cinema screen
item.description: BMW's electrifying new 7 Series luxury limo has been launched on an epic scale with its own giant cinema screen - and a tantalising choice of main features.

item.title: End of stamp duty break sees property sales fall by more than a third
item.description: Around 114,650 residential property transactions took place last month, which was 35.7 per cent less than in March 2021, but a 2.6 per cent rise compared with February 2022.

item.title: Calls for more help for cladding-hit flat owners after Commons vote
item.description: Protestors gathered outside Parliament to call for changes to the Building Safety Bill, as many leaseholders fear they could still have to pay life-changing sums.

item.title: Will my P&O Cruise be affected by P&O Ferries sackings?
item.description: I've booked a trip with P&O Cruises. Are the companies related and will my holiday be impacted?

item.title: Could space tourism and flying taxis make YOU rich in 2042?
item.description: For investors prepared to speculate there are themes and companies which could (I stress the word 'could') come good between now and 2042.

item.title: Bank of England walking 'tight line' in inflation battle, warns Bailey
item.description: Andrew Bailey (pictured) said there was a real risk that raising rates too fast slam Britain's economic recovery from the pandemic into reverse.

item.title: Natwest ups mortgage age limit to 75: Here's how to ensure you pay yours off by retirement
item.description: Rising retirement age and surging house prices mean many people are both working and paying off their home loans for longer.

item.title: An exclusive tour of Norwich's new electric car charging service station
item.description: The site hosts 36 chargers in total that can boost the batteries of any electric car ever sold in Britain, from decade-old models with sub-100-mile ranges to the latest long-distance Teslas.

item.title: How do I invest in gold? ETCs, mining stocks and physical bars options
item.description: I am worried about the impact of inflation on my investments and I have heard gold is a good hedge. What is the best way to invest in the commodity?

item.title: Silicone valley in the desert: Dubai isÂ investing for a high tech futureÂ
item.description: Dubai is obsessed with tech and innovation. Its economy now is focused on leisure, property and retail, but tech is where it sees its future prosperity.

item.title: Musk secures Â£36bn for Twitter takeover after record results at Tesla
item.description: Record results at electric car maker Tesla - where Musk (pictured) chief executive and the largest shareholder - put him in line for a Â£19bn bonus.

item.title: German giant gets in gear:Â Audi is driving towards an electric future
item.description: Audi, which already offers a wide range of electric motors like the e-tron GT (pictured), is to spend â¬18bn on electrification and hybridisation by 2026.

item.title: Hedge fund boss loses Â£300m in Netflix sale:Â Bill Ackman dumps stake
item.description: Hedge fund tycoon Bill Ackman (pictured) sold the Netflix stake he bought just three months ago, racking up a Â£300m loss in the process.

item.title: Bidders ARE interested in Â£7bn Boots, insists boss Seb James
item.description: The High Street chemist's US owner, the Walgreens Boots Alliance, announced in December it was planning to sell the 172-year-old chain.

item.title: Hut shares soar after firm snubs predators as private equity circles
item.description: Hut Group boss Matt Moulding (pictured with wife Jodie)Â said the company has received 'numerous' offers over the last few weeks.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: Reality check at the Hut as share price turns a corner
item.description: THG boss Matt Moulding (pictured) has decided at this stage it is better to take the hit on margins than alienate customers by full price recovery.

item.title: Britain's retailers are facing 'tsunami' of costs
item.description: Soaring costs endured by Britain's retailers could prove to be a 'permanent blow' for the sector, new findings haveÂ warned.

item.title: The Great British Rail Sale is trolling hard-hit commuters
item.description: Maybe, some commuters were so naÃ¯ve as to think that senior ministers had recognised their plight in a cost-of-living crisis. No such luck.

item.title: Tesla cheers record results as sales boom
item.description: In a bumper set of results just 24 hours after the Netflix horror show, the company reported revenues of Â£14.3billion for the first three months of 2022.

item.title: London-listed miners shares dive on weak production numbers
item.description: Anglo American, Antofagasta and BHP revealed a shortfall in first quarter production, which was blamed on Covid-related disruption and the impact of the Ukraine war.

item.title: Energy bill costs explained: Bosses warn of 40% in fuel poverty
item.description: Chief executives of UK's biggest energy firms told MPs that people on lower incomes would 'really struggle' if energy cap was hiked again in October.

item.title: What to do in the mortgage crunch and will rates keep rising? TiM podcast
item.description: For many homeowners it's been the case for some years that each time they remortgage, their rate comes down. That's no longer happening.

item.title: Underground car park space listed for Â£350k in Knightsbridge
item.description: A parking spot in one of the most expensive parts of the country is for sale with a hefty price tag. The area measures just 3.18 by 6.30 metres, or 10 ft 4 inches by 20 ft by 6 inches.

item.title: Frozen overseas state pensions: Nurse aged 100 in Australia gets just Â£46 a week
item.description: Patricia Coulthard, pictured, is one of nearly 500k expats around the world whose pensions are frozen at whatever amount they were set when they moved abroad.

item.title: Four in five now save into a pension compared to just 47% a decade ago
item.description: Four in five workers are now saving into a pension, compared to fewer than half a decade ago, new figures from the ONS.

item.title: Highway Code changes will outline rules for self-driving cars
item.description: Using a mobile phone, even when self-driving tech is active, will be banned. Ministers said this is due to the 'greater distraction risk' phones pose to drivers.

item.title: Millions of Briton's savings as risk as US tech stocks slide
item.description: Firms such as Netflix, Tesla and Amazon appear in the portfolios of many funds held in the pensions, Isas and other investments of UK households.

item.title: Missguided boss quits as fashion firm teeters on the brink of collapse
item.description: Missguided said its founder Nitin Passi will quit as chief exec and appointed consultancy Teneo to find a buyer or shut the business down.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: As bills keep on rising we need a fix for energy poverty
item.description: The current energy market is so disrupted by the unprecedented surge in wholesale oil and gas costs that comparison websites are in trouble.

item.title: MIDAS SHARE TIPS: Grow richer as UK gets older - with Impact Healthcare
item.description: Bosses Andrew Cowley and Mahesh Patel strive to make Impact's homes warm and welcoming. At Â£1.24, the stock is a long-term buy.

item.title: MIDAS SHARE TIPS UPDATE: Stream of dividends at BBGI
item.description: Midas recommended BBGI when the shares were Â£1.66. They have risen nearly 5 per cent. At Â£1.73, newcomers could buy a few shares.

item.title: EDINBURGH INVESTMENT TRUST: Flexibility is key
item.description: The Â£1billion trust, listed on the London Stock Exchange, is invested in 52 stocks, mostly UK.

item.title: SALLY SORTS IT: Virgin Money lost Â£15,000 I needed for cancer surgery
item.description: Due to a long NHS waiting list, I found it necessary to pay privately for prostate cancer surgery. The hospital requested I pay by card over the phone.

item.title: Beware the top savings rates that come with a catchÂ
item.description: There have been nearly 2,000 increases in easy-access deals in less than two months, but the accounts are becoming ever more complicated.

item.title: How second homeowners became the most hated people in Britain
item.description: Tempers flared again over the bank holiday, as residents in tourist meccas hit out at rich Londoners for treating the towns like 'Chelsea-on-Sea'.

item.title: Are unregulated pre-paid probate plans the new Wild West?
item.description: Experts warn that following a crackdown on pre-paid funeral plans, greedy salesmen have already shifted their attention to pre-paid probate plans.

item.title: Council tax rebate scam: Fraudsters target households desperate for help with bills
item.description: Councils across England have warned that criminals are calling and emailing residents to demand their bank details in order to process the rebate.

item.title: The secret broadband deals that could HALVE your bills
item.description: Around 4.2 million households are eligible for cheaper broadband. Yet just 55,000 have so far signed up for these low-cost deals, as providers failed to offer 'social tariffs' to struggling households

item.title: Mercedes Vision EQXX electric car completes 626-mile journey on a single charge
item.description: Bosses said the surplus charge would have provided enough power to cover an additional 87 miles, suggesting the car is capable of 713 miles on a full battery pack.

item.title: Hennessey releases 6X6 Mammoth 1000 TRX that costs $450k
item.description: Forget your Chelsea tractors - this new SUV is a Texas-tank. It's called the Hennessey Mammoth 1000 6X6 TRX and is as long as a small sailing yacht.

item.title: Does Musk's takeover bid make Twitter shares a bargain?
item.description: When the richest man on the planet announces he wants to take over a social media giant like Twitter, you expect it to make a splash.

item.title: Distance from London is most influential factor for house prices in towns
item.description: The ONS explained that being closer to London was the most important factor associated with higher property prices.

item.title: Will house prices keep rising? Knight Frank predicts end of the boom
item.description: Estate agent has predicted the UK property boom is about to end, with prices set to stagnate following years of sustained rises.

item.title: Natwest calls for green homeowners to get their stamp duty back
item.description: David Lindberg (pictured), boss of the Natwest's retail arm, said making UK homes more energy efficient is the most effective way to cut bills.

item.title: Is Britain's self-build boom over as costs go through the roof?
item.description: They're the ultimate symbol of individuality - homes designed and built to your specifications, perhaps with you doing some of the heavy lifting.

item.title: One in four workers fear they are not saving enough in their pension
item.description: Low-income households, women and people in their thirties and forties are the most concerned, new research shows.

item.title: Octopus energy pledges Â£50m to help struggling households
item.description: Octopus' chief exec Greg Jackson (pictured) said he is voluntarily shouldering losses during what he described as a 'once in 30-year crisis'.

item.title: Shock 1,800% rise in number of Britons hacked in cyber raids last year
item.description: More than 42m people in the UK were affected by data breaches as criminal gangs have ramp up their use of large-scale 'ransomware' attacks.

item.title: Victim of cryptocurrency fraud thanks us for return of Â£8,500
item.description: Andrew France saw his money disappear after trading crypto assets through InvestXE, a company incorporated in Dominica.

item.title: Phil Spencer on property prices and top tips for home movers
item.description: He says that moving home should be 'exciting' but problems typically crop up because it is a 'complex process with many moving parts.'

item.title: TONY HETHERINGTON: Losing Â£10,000 was NO laughing matter
item.description: The contract guaranteed my money back and I was to receive a further Â£2,500 plus a percentage of sale proceeds, but the film bombed.

item.title: Renew your passport now - it could take TEN weeks
item.description: The Passport Office is expecting an unprecedented wave of applications following two years of pandemic travel restrictions.

item.title: Best stocks & shares Isas: Pick the right DIY investment platform
item.description: Choosing the right DIY platform is crucial but a wealth of choice and a variety of charges can leave investors scratching their heads. We pick some of the best.

item.title: Best mortgage rates: Compare fixed rate and tracker rate mortgage deals
item.description: The average two-year and five-year fixed rate increased again in April, reaching 2.86% and 3.01% respectively.

item.title: Best cash Isas 2022: Where to get the best cash Isa rates and deals
item.description: We pick our five favourite cash Isas for savers. This is essential Isa reading and is kept up-to-date throughout the year

item.title: How to invest in shares
item.description: If you are interested in buying shares or know more about unearthing good companies and valuing them, read our guide to share investing.

item.title: Ten tips for buy-to-let: Essential advice for property investment
item.description: Buy-to-let lost some of its spark in recent years but that might be about to change as new tax cuts and low mortgage rates have caused landlords to flock back to the market.

item.title: Classic car found under rubbish in a late father-in-law's garage could sell for Â£70k
item.description: After the stack of boxes, dust sheets and deckchairs were removed from the old British motor, it was lovingly restored. The car will be offered to the highest bidder in May and could sell for Â£70k.

item.title: MARKET REPORT: Mining shares in a hole updates as production slumps
item.description: Anglo American slumped 8.8% after trimming its full-year guidance in the wake of a slower first quarter. Meanwhile, Antofagasta fell 7.1%.

item.title: Card Factory shares skyrocket as retailer declares new refinancing deal
item.description: Card Factory shares jumped 31.9 per cent to 59.7p on late Thursday afternoon, making it the second-highest riser on the FTSE All-Share Index.

item.title: BUSINESS LIVE: Musk to launch Twitter tender offer; Deloitte sanctions
item.description: The FTSE 100 closed down 1.27 points at 7627.95.Among UK companies with reports and updates are THG, Meggit, Foxtons and AJ Bell.

item.title: Ibstock shares jump as brick maker posts upbeat update
item.description: The FTSE 250-listed brick maker said its first quarter performance had been stronger than expected, driven by an upturn in clay brick sales volumes and decent margins.

item.title: EDF sent me a shock bill and set debt collectors on me
item.description: I submitted final meter readings to the old supplier when I moved in, but EDF now claims I used an extra 9,000 kWh of energy - and I have no idea why.

item.title: Rio Tinto warns over inflation, China lockdowns and war in Ukraine
item.description: Rio shipped 71.5m tonnes of the key steelmaking ingredient in the first three months of the year. This was 15% less than in the previous three months.

item.title: 40bn wiped off Netflix value as subscriber shock rocks shares
item.description: The slump slashed the value of the California-based giant, which produces the hit show Bridgerton (pictured) by just over Â£40bn to Â£75bn.

item.title: MARKET REPORT: Just Eat on the menu as it ponders Grubhub sale
item.description: Just Eat shares rose after it revealed it was 'exploring' a sale of its US arm Grubhub or bringing in a partner to offload a stake in the business.

item.title: Comparison site Energy Helpline collapses into administration
item.description: The 20-year-old website provides customers with a free energy switching service to help them find the cheapest gas and electricity deal.

item.title: GlaxoSmithKline workers vote to strike in a row over pay
item.description: Members of the Unite Union, which comprise around 700 of GSK's 13,000-strong UK workforce, voted 86% in favour of industrial action.

item.title: FCA to let firms exclude trans women from gender diversity targets
item.description: Boards should be at least 40% female, and include one person from an ethnic minority background, according to the Financial Conduct Authority.

item.title: Credit Suisse forced to set aside ANOTHER Â£566m for legal costs
item.description: Credit Suisse, which has been involved in a string of scandals, is set to book a loss for the first quarter of 2022, after it swung into the red at the end of 2021.

item.title: Just Eat Takeaway ponders sale of Grubhub after extensive investor pressure
item.description: Bosses at the online food delivery service have said they were 'actively exploring' whether to conduct a full or partial sale of its US-based subsidiary.

item.title: Oxford Biomedica shares plummet by 15% on lower revenue warning
item.description: Oxford Biomedica shares plunged 14.7 per cent to Â£5.45 on Wednesday, making it the second-largest faller on the FTSE 350 Index.

item.title: BUSINESS LIVE: JustEat dampens expectations; Wood Group losses narrow
item.description: The FTSE 100 closed up 27.94 points at 7629.22. Among UK companies with reports and updates are 888, Oxford Biomedica and Quilter. Read the Wednesday 20 April Business Live blog below.

item.title: Would an electric car save you money? Study breaks down the costs
item.description: Drivers who go all-electric can save an average of Â£3,862 over seven years, Meanwhile, some cars on lease and PCP deals are cheaper, but others are not.

item.title: Peak Netflix? Streaming giant's investors set for painful road ahead
item.description: Netflix shares plummeted 25% in after-hours trading on Tuesday, bringing 2022 losses to 41.6%, after the firm revealed its first net decline in subscribers in 10 years.

item.title: Government plans to make hosting fake online reviews illegal
item.description: The CMA could be given new powers to crack down on fake online reviews to stop companies exploiting customers and trapping them in unwanted subscription services.

item.title: CRH shares jump as sales and margins grow in first quarter
item.description: The group, which is based in Ireland, also expects sales, earnings and margins to come in in higher than expected by the end of the first half.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: Is the IMF downplaying the risk to British growth?
item.description: The spring edition of the IMF's World Economic Outlook contains warnings about the 'unprecedented nature of the shocks' to the global economy.

item.title: VICTORIA BISCHOFF: Regulators must wake up to the probate plan threat
item.description: Sound the alarm bells. Fire up the klaxon. There is a new unregulated business in town - Pre-paid probate plans that promise families peace of mind.

item.title: MARKET REPORT: Inflation fears take a bite out of Upper Crust owner
item.description: Shares in the Upper Crust and Ritazza owner slumped 6.3% after analysts at Deutsche Bank downgraded the stock to 'hold' from 'buy'.

item.title: Shock as 200,000 subscribers quit Netflix sending shares crashing 25%
item.description: Netflix has produced hits including political drama Anatomy of a Scandal, starring Naomi Scott, Sienna Miller and Michelle Dockery (pictured).

item.title: Wood Group boss Robin Watson to retire after enduring tough year
item.description: Watson was appointed chief executive of the Aberdeen-based group in January 2016, having previously joined the board in January 2013 as boss of Wood's PSN division.

item.title: Moscow shares snub is latest blow for Putin
item.description: The decision by HMRC means investors with shares in companies listed in Moscow will no longer be able to access certain tax benefits.

item.title: Watchdog blasts London Metal Exchange over nickel trading debacle
item.description: The IMF accused the LME of potentially harming 'free and fair markets' when it cancelled a slew of trades as the price of nickel surged to record highs.

item.title: Vauxhall owner Stellantis becomes latest firm to pull out of Russia
item.description: Vauxhall-owner Stellantis, which is one of the largest car-makers in the world, suspended its vehicle production in the western city of Kaluga (pictured).

item.title: LV chiefs squandered more owners' cash on bonuses and payoffs
item.description: Chief exec Mark Hartigan (pictured) is already under fire for spending Â£33m on the ill-fated attempt to sell LV to private equity firm Bain Capital last year.

item.title: Cake Box boasts of record year on back of surging online demand
item.description: Cake Box said it expects to declare adjusted pre-tax earnings in line with market forecasts alongside a hike in revenues of about 50 per cent for the 12 months to March 31.

item.title: TDR Capital's investment in Asda has already risen 20-fold
item.description: London-based TDR Capital has valued its stake in the grocer at about Â£1.4billion, which it said is 19.8 times the amount it paid, according to reports.

item.title: Robinhood buys UK crypto startup Ziglu
item.description: Robinhood has agreed to buy UK crypto start-up Ziglu as the investment platform steps up its crypto push and once again tries to expand into Britain.

item.title: Genesis electric GV60 coupÃ© set for Euro debut
item.description: Pricing for the model ranges from Â£47,005 to Â£65,405, and pre-order books have opened for the brand's first electric platform-based vehicle.

item.title: What are Real Returns? Investing Explained
item.description: To calculate the real return from a savings account, say, you would subtract the current rate of inflation from the 'nominal' or advertised rate.

item.title: Filter out bogus deals on prescription shades
item.description: But rather than opt for an eye-catching special offer or online promotion that often ends up costing more than expected, you should focus on exactly what you need.

item.title: Musk targets Twitter board as he steps up efforts to buy the company
item.description: Musk (pictured) stunned both Wall Street and Silicon Valley last week when he swooped on the social media group with a Â£31bn takeover offer.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: Russia's war in Ukraine puts World order under stress
item.description: The pandemic, followed by Russia's war in Ukraine has laid bare fundamental weaknesses in the way in which core institutions of international finance work.

item.title: Lending gives profits at Bank of America a surprise boostÂ
item.description: Bank of America chief exec Brian Moynihan (pictured) said customers had spent at the highest level ever recorded for the first quarter.

item.title: Fears Sri Lankan economy could collapse after it halts debt payments
item.description: Despite suffering many catastrophes since winning its independence from Britain in 1948, Sri Lanka has never reneged on its debts.

item.title: Female boards were more likely to cut executive pay in the pandemic
item.description: Fewer than half of firms worth more than Â£500m or more made cuts, according to a study by the High Pay Centre think tank.

item.title: Cinven on hunt for Â£1bn UK tech firm Ideagen
item.description: Cinven is mulling a bid for Ideagen, which sells software to help businesses and governments comply with regulations.

item.title: Budget airline Wizz Air boosts cabin crew wages
item.description: Wizz has raised wages by 12.5 per cent for cabin crew, who will now be guaranteed 70 per cent of their overallÂ annual salary.

item.title: Bentley boss wants to carry on doing business with customers in Russia
item.description: The firm stopped selling new cars in Russia when Vladimir Putin mounted his attack. However, it wants to carry on supporting existing vehicle owners.

item.title: Lottery chairman once worked for Kremlin's top investment bank
item.description: Stephen Cohen chairs the National Lottery Competition Committee which last month handed the licence to Allwyn Entertainment.

item.title: They're meant to stop fraud, but online payment checks are frustrating
item.description: So-called 'strong customer authentication' rules mean anyone buying an item over the internet may need to verify a transaction with their bank.

item.title: Barclays chairman in hot seat over Â£11.5bn trading blunder
item.description: Nigel Higgins will be meeting top shareholders to be questioned about the debacle ahead of the bank's annual meeting next month.

item.title: Next snaps up boutique kids' goods business JoJo Maman BÃ©bÃ©
item.description: It has taken a 44 per cent stake in JoJo, with the remainder bought by asset manager Davidson Kempner. Next did not say how much it paid.

item.title: Carnival sails into storm over chief Arnold Donald's Â£11.4m
item.description: In an embarrassment for the FTSE 250 firm, 36 per cent voted against its pay report. It will now join the executive pay 'list of shame'.

item.title: KEN COSTA: The 'g' of governance needs to focus on generosity
item.description: Something tells me that in British public life our famed tolerance doesn't extend as far where business and finance are concerned.

item.title: Investors in Cineworld urged to vote against pay policy
item.description: The two brothers at the top of the debt-laden cinema chain have been handed share awards which could be worth Â£65million.

item.title: British stocks to protect your portfolio from soaring inflation
item.description: Games Workshop, Rightmove and Ocado are among the London-listed stocks best placed to shield investors from soaring inflation, new research suggests.

item.title: Richard Desmond in legal bid to overturn lottery deal
item.description: Desmond's Northern & Shell and a subsidiary, the New Lottery Company, have taken legal action against the Gambling Commission.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: Pitfalls of overseas control
item.description: As a long-standing critic of foreign ownership of vital infrastructure I find it comforting that Schroders is coming round to the same view.

item.title: PensionBee revenues jump as more savers consolidate their pension pots
item.description: The company's assets under management rose to Â£2.6billion in 2021, from Â£1.4billion in 2020, as existing and new customers handed over more of their savings.

item.title: National Grid sparks fury as it cashes in on soaring electricity costs
item.description: National Grid risks anger from politicians and the public after hiking its forecasts as the soaring cost of electricity boosted profits.

item.title: Twitter deploys poison pill to fend off Elon Musk
item.description: The company will flood the market with new shares if Musk takes his stake above 15 per cent, diluting the value of his holding.

item.title: Serena Williams pumps more than $1m into British sports venture
item.description: OpenSponsorship, founded by Manchester-born entrepreneur Ishveen Jolly, is a site that connects athletes with sponsor brands.

item.title: Two of world's most powerful investors betting against Marks & Spencer
item.description: We can reveal that BlackRock, the world's biggest asset manager, and hedge fund Marshall Wace are shorting the retailer's stock.

item.title: Phones billionaire John Caudwell is latest to blast the refugee visa fiasco
item.description: Dubbed Britain's biggest taxpayer at the peak of his success, Caudwell is never shy of telling the Tories how they could do their job better.

item.title: TV's Andrea McLean talks to ME & MY MONEY
item.description: Andrea lost most of her pension investment in the insurer, but she has bounced back since, and now runs her own online gym for the mind.

item.title: Ratings agency warns Russia may have already defaulted on its debt
item.description: The default would mark the first time Russia has failed to repay its foreign debts since the Bolshevik revolution in 1917.

item.title: Piano maker Steinway will list on New York Stock Exchange
item.description: Demand shot higher during the pandemic as people stayed at home and, in 2021, sales increased by 30 per cent to Â£411.7m.

item.title: What lessons can Britain learn from Dubai, asks RUTH SUNDERLAND
item.description: It is unlikely to turn itself into a desert nirvana by 2071 or at any other time, but it is already an elusive and beguiling enigma.

item.title: Crypto firm touted by David Beckham 'fleeced investors'
item.description: We can reveal DigitalBits bosses are facing allegations that they diverted money from developing its technology to fund luxury travel and sports deals.

item.title: HAMISH MCRAE: Time to be positive over economy amid gloom
item.description: It may be the most troubling Easter we have experienced, and there is nothing an economic commentator can write to make it less so.

item.title: JEFF PRESTRIDGE: Chancellor must stop stalling over access to cash
item.description: Choice in payment methods should be a financial right. We should not allow the banks to railroad us into a cashless society.

item.title: Safe Hands funeral cash was used to buy commercial property
item.description: A petition has now been launched demanding that the Government set up an emergency fund to support victims Ernest and Pat Hughes paid Â£3,395.

item.title: Lloyds may strip ex-boss Horta-Osorio of Â£1m bonus over HBOS
item.description: The bank's remuneration committee is deciding whether to punish Sir Antonio for his role in the episode by clawing back a chunk of his pay packet.

item.title: STOCKS TO WATCH: No one's TalkTalking about sale of mobile firm
item.description: The mobile firm has asked investment bankers at Lazard to manage a sale process. Vodafone and Sky have already been touted as possible buyers.

item.title: Battle to take over Boots entering its closing stages
item.description: Britain's biggest chemist has been up for sale since January as its owner, US giant Walgreens, looks to turn its focus to healthcare in the States.

item.title: Diversifying your savings will help avoid storms ahead
item.description: You may think that your portfolio is diversified, sheltering you from storms. But could this be an illusion?

item.title: THG set to unveil final results for 2021 with update on 2022
item.description: THG, which floated as the Hut Group, will be hoping a robust outlook for 2022 can put some spark back into its once-adored stock.

item.title: How can we save a house deposit in a cost of living crisis?
item.description: We want to buy a home in the next three years, but feel that the goalposts are constantly shifting. How can we make the most of our savings?

item.title: The St. James's Place gravy train rumbles on despite pledge to reform
item.description: St. James's Place, led by chief exec Andrew Croft (pictured), was left reeling in 2019 after details of its opulent culture - paid for by clients - were laid bare.

item.title: A brand new car at a used car price: Citroen launches the C3 YOU!
item.description: As the cost-of-living crisis begins to bite for most of us, Citroen has brought out a new bargain basement hatchback trim level - the C3 YOU!

item.title: Asia's richest man Mukesh Ambani joins the bidding war for BootsÂ
item.description: Mukesh Ambani (pictured), the eldest son of Reliance founder Dhirubhai Ambani, could table a bid or team up with another buyer to take a stake in Boots.

item.title: Ethical vs traditional funds - which have the investing performance edge?
item.description: 'Genuine' consumer demand, the fund industry's embrace of responsible investing and regulatory changes will drive the popularity of this sector in future, says Laith Khalaf of AJ Bell.

item.title: Musk swoops on Twitter with Â£31bn takeover bidÂ
item.description: Tesla tycoon Musk (pictured) has made an offer of $54.20 a share just days after he rejected an invitation to join the company's board.

item.title: Wall Street profits sunk in first quarter of 2022
item.description: Goldman's profits slid 42%, but it was boosted by its trading division, which seemed to navigate the volatility better than some of its peers.

item.title: Ukraine war a 'massive setback' for the global recovery, says IMF boss
item.description: Kristalina Georgieva (pictured) said 'we are facing a crisis on top of a crisis', with war in Ukraine intensifying problems caused by Covid.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: Sanctions lose their bite as Russian gas keeps flowing
item.description: Glee over the misery of Russia's oligarchs is palpable. The pleasure in seeing the world's biggest yachts seized cannot be understated.

item.title: MARKET REPORT: Wizz Air shares take off amid summer bookings boom
item.description: Wizz Air rose as much as 7.8% after revealing that it was preparing to ramp up its operations and crew numbers in preparation for 'a busy summer'.

item.title: Student loan interest rates shouldn't be 12% - and RPI must be ditched
item.description: The student loan system bases interest on retail prices index inflation - a measure considered dubious enough not to be an official national statistic - and then adds 3%.

item.title: BUSINESS CLOSE: Musk Twitter bid; Dunelm sales up
item.description: The FTSE 100 has closed 0.5 per cent higher at 7,616.4, while the FTSE 250 has ended the day up 0.7 per cent at 21,121.6.

item.title: Furniture retailer Dunelm sees sales jump to nearly Â£400m
item.description: Sales in the 13 weeks to 26 March climbed 69 per cent to Â£399million from the equivalent period last year when the group's outlets were shut while England was experiencing its third national lockdown.
